2.98.text:
OK, so we’ve looked at God’s love between
the persons of the Trinity- let’s look now

8.89.text:
at Part 2, God’s Love for Us
And a good place to begin is to see that bible

16.31.text:
presents 4 different ways that God loves us
This is helpful, because some of the confusion

22.93.text:
we have about God’s love comes from us only
concentrating on one of these ways and forgetting

29.08.text:
about the others, rather than holding them
all together (I’m going to run through them

34.37.text:
very quickly but you can read about these,
and the some of the other topics of this talk

39.30.text:
more fully in Don Carson’s brilliant book-
the Difficult Doctrine of the Love of God).

46.38.text:
So 4 different ways that God loves us…
Firstly there is ‘Common Grace’ love-

55.05.text:
this is God’s providential love over all
that he has made. It does not differentiate

60.92.text:
between any of his creators. God creates and
lovingly pronounces everything he has made

66.88.text:
‘good’. He lovingly sends the rain on
the righteous and the unrighteous in Matthew

73.25.text:
5 and no sparrow falls without his loving
providence in Matthew 6. Oldy worldy theology

80.03.text:
calls this ‘Common Grace’- God loves everyone
and everything without distinction in this

86.79.text:
sense.
But if we only concentrate on this alone,

91.57.text:
we could be left with that idea of God’s
love primarily being a bit like a ‘forcefield

97.53.text:
of loving energy’ which is clearly insufficient…
So secondly, the bible presents God having

105.03.text:
a ‘Wanting No Sinner to Perish’ kind of
love. ‘For God so loved the world that he

111.60.text:
gave his one and only son’ says Jn 3:16.
This is God’s love for the whole fallen

118.61.text:
world, a world that is at war with him. He
lovingly invites and commands all to repent,

124.27.text:
yearning for and not wanting anyone to perish
as in 2 Peter 3, and cries out as in Ezekiel

131.94.text:
33.11 to ‘Turn Turn from your evil ways,
Why will you die.’

139.26.text:
But if we only stress this kind of love, to
the exclusion of the rest of the bible’s

144.20.text:
teaching on God’s love we are left with
a picture of God who is only waiting for our

151.12.text:
repentance. God is unable to intervene to
save us since our salvation is ultimately

156.62.text:
down to our choice. And that leaves us unsure
as to whether we will get to heaven or not…

163.83.text:
So thirdly we need the bible’s presentation
of God’s ‘Electing, Saving’ love. The

172.07.text:
elect in the bible just means a specific person
or group of people that God has chosen and

177.13.text:
separated out from the rest. In the OT it’s
often his people, Israel, and in the NT it’s

184.00.text:
his people the church, and also individual
believers. God’s electing love means God

190.06.text:
exclusively, i.e. to the exclusion of the
rest, sets his affection on some, and saves

197.40.text:
those people.
Moses tells Israel in Deut 10.15 ‘Yet the

204.58.text:
LORD set his affection on your forefathers
and loved them, and he chose you, their descendants,

209.70.text:
above all the nations, as it is today’,
and Paul tells the Ephesians in chapter 1:

215.10.text:
4-5 ‘For God chose us in him before the
creation of the world… in love he predestined

222.08.text:
us to be adopted as sons’.
The reason that God choses people is not because

228.58.text:
of their merit or any other personal qualities.
He choses them purely and simply because he

231.40.text:
loves them. Listen to Moses talking to Israel
again in Deut 7: ‘The Lord did not set his

234.38.text:
affection on you and choose you because you
were more numerous than other peoples, for

235.38.text:
you were the fewest of all peoples. 8But it
was because the Lord loved you Deut 7:7-8

236.38.text:
So that’s God’s electing, saving love-
out of love he choses some but not all people

244.06.text:
But if we only stress this love and forget
his yearning love for the whole world to be

249.53.text:
saved, we might be less likely to do evangelism-
but it’s because God longs for all to be

256.05.text:
saved (i.e. the number 2 type love) that he
sends us to all nations. Can you begin to

262.76.text:
see how we need to hold all 4 aspects of God’s
love for us together…?

268.90.text:
Lastly the bible presents God’s ‘disciplining’
love. This is God’s love for his people

274.70.text:
that is conditional on their obedience.
Hang on- those of you who are awake maybe

282.42.text:
saying- ‘God’s love is conditional on
obedience? That’s not right- what about

288.29.text:
grace? Isn’t the point of God’s love to
be unconditional? Well the answer is that

294.38.text:
God’s love is both unconditional and conditional,
just in different senses. It is unconditional

302.92.text:
when it comes to our salvation, but also conditional
when it comes to how we relate to him as our

308.97.text:
heavenly father.
As we know- God’s unconditional love is

314.44.text:
his elective, saving love, this is how we
become one of God’s people- this is the

320.76.text:
love of God that we can never be separated
from this side of heaven (Romans 8) and it

326.14.text:
is never conditional on our obedience- grace
not works- and we cannot walk away from that

333.29.text:
love.
But as a redeemed child of God, our heavenly

339.35.text:
father is not indifferent to our sin- and
if we sin, he will discipline us by removing

346.45.text:
his love for a time and he will view us with
wrath, in some sense. We are told, as in Jude

354.32.text:
21 ‘Keep yourselves in God’s love’ and
by Jesus ‘If you obey my commands, you will

359.51.text:
remain in my love’ Jn 15:9 i.e. it is possible
in some sense not to ‘keep oneself’ or

367.56.text:
not to ‘remain’ in God’s love. It’s
a bit like our human parent-child relationships:

375.62.text:
We will always love our children fundamentally,
but if a child, for example, is very disobedient,

381.88.text:
for the sake of their disciplining, we may
withdraw our love for a period (be it the

388.82.text:
naughty-step, or grounding them) to bring
them back to obedience.

393.95.text:
(And as an aside- this disciplining love is
really important to remember when we slack

401.47.text:
off at our holiness, thinking God ‘has’
to love us, in every sense, no matter what.

407.66.text:
If we think this we need to pinch ourselves
and listen to the advice to Jude to ‘Keep

413.54.text:
yourself in God’s love)
So back to the main idea- 4 ways God loves

420.47.text:
us. If we pull all this together- particularly
when what we read something about God’s

425.57.text:
love that seems to contradict another part
of the bible- it can be very helpful to think

430.52.text:
about which of these 4 aspects of God’s
love for us is being stressed, rather than

435.83.text:
the default of just presuming that God loves
everything, the same way, all the time.

441.67.text:
Right, now we’ve galloped through that survey,
let’s ask the next question –what’s

448.99.text:
God’s love for us really like…what does
it actually mean to be loved by God?

456.31.text:
By this I mean does he love us like a kindly
uncle? Or as a desperate lover, overrun with

465.53.text:
passion? Or as a charitable benefactor- fairly
but unemotionally handing out good things?

474.74.text:
Well to understand God’s love for us we
need to know a bit more about what God is

478.86.text:
like generally:
So WHAT IS GOD LIKE? (bear with me on this

485.25.text:
one- in the next couple of minutes we’ll
look at few key things about God and then,

490.83.text:
with them in our minds, we’ll think about
God’s love again in the light of them…)

496.39.text:
Firstly God is utterly sovereign- he’s all
powerful, he’s omnipotent, able to do anything

506.89.text:
Ah, Sovereign LORD, you have made the heavens
and the earth by your great power and outstretched

514.33.text:
arm. Nothing is too hard for you jer 32:17
His sovereignty is all encompassing- from

522.28.text:
the movement of the stars isa 40:26, to the
throw of a dice (Prov 16.33) all is determined

528.66.text:
by God. He doesn’t just wind the world up
like a clock and let it run, but is intimately

533.84.text:
involved with everything that happens, upholding
everything by his powerful word Heb 1:3. Nothing

541.50.text:
happens outside of his control because he
works out everything according to the purpose

547.64.text:
of his will, Eph 1:11, including sentient
beings like you and me. We only chose within

557.57.text:
whatever God wills: Proverbs 21:1 says ‘The
king’s heart is a stream of water in the

565.12.text:
hand of the LORD; he turns it wherever he
will.’

569.91.text:
God’s sovereignty also means he’s all
knowing- that’s omniscient- he knows everything!

578.15.text:
He even has middle knowledge—which means
God knows what might have been under different

583.68.text:
circumstances (yes get your head around that!-
it’s in Matthew 11:20-24.) He also knows

590.74.text:
our free, future decisions 1 Sam 23:11, and
his knowledge is perfect from before eternity

598.70.text:
Job 37 16 so he’s never surprised as things
happen, since he knew it all before time began.

606.02.text:
As Wayne Grudem says ‘God does not have
to reason to conclusions or ponder carefully

612.86.text:
before he answers, for he knows the end from
the beginning, and he never learns and never

619.50.text:
forgets anything’ 2 Peter 3:8
This eternal existing outside time and space

626.87.text:
is called God’s transcendence: he ‘lives
forever’ Isa 57:15. Precisely because he

633.60.text:
is creator, he must be separate and independent
from creation: it cannot limit him and therefore

640.86.text:
he can’t but know everything.
So however we understand God’s love it has

650.17.text:
to go hand in hand with this fact of God’s
sovereignty. His love for us cannot mean that

656.99.text:
it makes him in anyway less powerless to act
(like a desperate lover waiting for us to

663.54.text:
choose his salvation), or that his love for
us means he lacks any knowledge about our

668.88.text:
past or future actions (i.e he cannot in any
way be ‘blinded by love’ such that he

675.33.text:
fails to see our sin).
So- God is utterly sovereign. And that means

681.84.text:
he’s sovereign over election. We’ve already
looked at God’s love in election, and what

683.81.text:
we need to add here is that God’s electing
love goes hand in hand with his utter sovereignty

684.81.text:
and power. He has no less control over his
predestination, choice, and redemption of

690.54.text:
his chosen people than anything else in the
universe- i.e. his sovereignty over election

695.21.text:
is total. So his electing love cannot be overridden
by external influences (such as our decisions

703.48.text:
or actions)- Jesus tells us in Jn 6:39 that
‘I shall lose none of all those he has given

714.59.text:
me’
Next God is also immutable (i.e. unchanging)

720.48.text:
God says ‘I the LORD do not change’ in
Mal 3:6, Now God being unchanging doesn’t

728.93.text:
mean God is frozen still- that he doesn’t
interact with us in our time- he does obviously,

735.63.text:
it rather means that his very being and his
purposes don’t change

741.85.text:
Isaiah 46: 10 I make known the end from the
beginning, from ancient times, what is still

749.20.text:
to come. I say, 'My purpose will stand, and
I will do all that I please.

757.25.text:
Unlike us, his creatures, who are changeable,
striving and seeking rest and satisfaction,

764.24.text:
God is without needs externally- we can rest
in him because he is the unchangeable Rock.

775.81.text:
So…what happens when God’s unchangeableness,
his immutability is expressed through his

783.82.text:
emotions? The bible reveals a God who is impassible-
classically described as ‘without passions’.

794.01.text:
This means that God’s emotions cannot be
changed against his will by outside circumstances.

801.70.text:
Whilst God reacts with emotion to the outside
world, his emotions are never dictated by

809.01.text:
it. As Don Carson says he has no emotion that
‘makes him vulnerable from the outside,

816.15.text:
less than perfect, over which he has no control
or has not foreseen’. God’s love does

823.15.text:
not make God himself change. This is very
different to human love, that changes us deeply.

829.97.text:
We fall in love and we’re a different person.
But God’s love cannot change God, because

835.64.text:
he never changes.
So God is all powerful, all knowing, sovereign

843.94.text:
over election, unchanging and impassible.
So let’s repeat our question…how does

851.79.text:
God love us? What sort of love can a God like
this have…it might now seem that God ‘the

860.28.text:
Rock’ might not be able to love at all in
the sense we understand? Can God really feel

868.26.text:
emotion?
When Israel was a child, I loved him,

878.99.text:
and out of Egypt I called my son. (God talking
in Hosea of his rebellious people…)

885.87.text:
2 But the more they were called,
the more they went away from me.[a]

890.47.text:
They sacrificed to the Baals
and they burned incense to images.

895.05.text:
3 It was I who taught Ephraim (that’s Israel)
to walk,

899.42.text:
taking them by the arms;
but they did not realize

902.99.text:
it was I who healed them.
4 I led them with cords of human kindness,

908.04.text:
with ties of love.
To them I was like one who lifts

911.53.text:
a little child to the cheek,
and I bent down to feed them.

916.03.text:
5 “Will they not return to Egypt (meaning:
Will I not judge them by sending them back

923.59.text:
into slavery?)
and will not Assyria rule over them

932.66.text:
“How can I give you up, Ephraim?
How can I hand you over, Israel?...

937.09.text:
My heart is changed within me;
all my compassion is aroused.

941.41.text:
9 I will not carry out my fierce anger,
nor will I devastate Ephraim again.

947.67.text:
For I am God, and not a man—
the Holy One among you.

952.68.text: I will not come against their cities

958.46.text:
This is God talking in Hosea 11. Have a look
back over what he says. The eternal unchangeable,

968.37.text:
impassible God tenderly cared for Israel as
for a child, v3: ‘It was I who taught Ephraim

975.65.text:
to walk’, his hands out round their chubby
arms to stop them from falling, healed their

980.31.text:
scraped knees and v4: ‘I led them’, pulling
them along not with a pram or kiddy-reigns-

985.95.text:
but ‘with cords of human kindness, with
ties love’. ‘like one who lifts a little

991.41.text:
child to the cheek,’ to nuzzle their soft
downy skin, and stooping down to feed them

997.23.text:
their first mouthfuls…
But… v3b: ‘They did not realise it was

1003.62.text:
I who healed them’- they didn’t acknowledge
their Father’s passionate love. And just

1009.06.text:
like a teenager heading down the front path
without a backwards look v2: God says ‘the

1014.97.text:
more they were called , the more they went
away from me’.

1019.44.text:
So God says v5 ‘Will they not return to
Egypt’ meaning I will judge them and exile

1027.05.text:
them to Egypt and beyond. A terrifying prospect….
But, then another twist in v 8, ‘ How can

1034.68.text:
I give you up’ he cries out in anguish-
judgement will not be the final word, ‘all

1040.93.text:
my compassion is aroused’, and then in from
v9 to the chapter end he vows to bring them

1046.76.text:
back from exile.
…So whatever we say about God’s sovereignty

1056.85.text:
and unchangeableness, we can’t deny that
God’s love for us is a 100% deep emotion.

1066.43.text:
God’s love is neither that of kindly uncle,
nor distant charitable benefactor but the

1074.23.text:
love of a passionate Father.
So what on earth are we to do this passionate

1083.72.text:
love, and the fact that God is impassible,
that ‘I the Lord do not change’ that his

1093.03.text:
emotions cannot be changed against his will
by outside circumstances. And it’s that

1100.19.text:
extra bit of that sentence that is so important-
that his emotions cannot be changed against

1105.61.text:
his will by outside circumstances. By this
we mean God’s emotions, & in particular

1111.97.text:
his passionate love for us is not given to
mood swings, capriciousness, or is in any

1118.14.text:
way dependent on his creatures. Whereas our
love changes, and bends our will, surprises

1125.25.text:
us and changes our commitments, God’s love
is entirely under his control- and is in total

1133.14.text:
harmony with his power, knowledge and will.
So… the conclusion of all this is that God’s

1143.82.text:
love for us is passionate but unchanging.
And hence it is misleading to say that God

1153.81.text:
‘falls in love’ with us, which carries
with it our connotations of uncontrollable

1158.77.text:
and therefore changeable and therefore unreliable
human passion. Instead the bible says that

1165.52.text:
God ‘sets his love (or affection) on his
elect’ Deut 7:7.

1171.54.text:
And therefore know that, if you are a Christian,
God hasn’t ‘fallen in love with you’

1180.99.text:
with all the insecurities that new love can
entail. No God has ‘set his love on you’

1188.09.text:
before the creation of the world. That means
the all sovereign, all powerful, all knowing

1195.44.text:
God, who knew everything you’d ever do,
the God who’ll never change that perfect

1200.60.text:
plan for your salvation, that God chose you.
And not randomly, not because anything provoked

1207.11.text:
him to, but just because before the beginning
of time he loved you.

1219.94.text:
And yet there’s still more to say about
what God’s love for us is really like. So

1227.78.text:
let’s move onto point 6 … it’s this:
God loves us despite our unloveliness, at

1235.38.text:
great cost. And this is related to the previous
idea of God’s unchanging love. Basically

1244.09.text:
his electing love can not be affected by our
bad qualities (nor our good either) because

1249.83.text:
his love for us comes only out of his unchanging
will and purposes rather than because we’ve

1256.02.text:
caused it.
1 john 4:10 tells us ‘This is love, not

1261.85.text:
that we loved God, but that he loved us and
sent his Son to be the propitiation for our

1265.31.text:
sins’
God loves and saves us despite our unloveliness-

1268.92.text:
it’s ‘not that we loved God’ as John
says, not that we’ve done anything, in fact

1274.33.text:
it’s worse, it’s whilst we were God’s
sinning enemies, that he loved us.

1279.13.text:
It’s as if God says to us ‘I know what
you’re like, I see what you do in private.

1287.55.text:
I know and am grieved by the evil you do,
by your unholiness, by your unloveliness,

1295.17.text:
by your rejection of me but despite all this
I love you more than anyone ever could. I

1303.81.text:
love you, not because of what you are like
but for loves sake only. And because of that-

1309.95.text:
nothing you can do with ever stop me loving
you, because my love was never based on what

1316.55.text:
you do in the first place’
So… if we truly get this we’ll stop battling

1326.21.text:
to earn a place in God’s family, to secure
his love, by being lovely… and (on the flip

1331.38.text:
side) we’ll stop preening over the loveliness
we do have, thinking that’s the reason he

1338.94.text:
loved and chose us because it wasn’t.
And following on from this, if we know anything

1348.22.text:
of the gospel, we know that God loves us at
great cost. This is the true measure of his

1355.53.text:
love for us…
Read 1 John 4:10 again on your sheets

1360.68.text:
‘This is love, not that we loved God, but
that he loved us and sent his Son to be the

1367.11.text:
propitiation for our sins’
Let’s just slow down for a minute and think

1374.34.text:
about the details of what John’s really
saying here. John says he loved us and sent

1379.95.text:
his Son, that the Son, the second person of
the eternal trinity, who’s everything we’ve

1385.78.text:
just been talking about- all powerful, all
knowing, transcendent, immutable- he was willingly

1392.79.text:
sent to inhabit a frail human body.
he loved us and sent his Son, sent from his

1402.77.text:
throne in heaven to not even the luxury of
the 21st century world, but to a dangerous,

1409.37.text:
agrarian, medicine free existence. And sent
from the worship and adoration of the angels

1415.80.text:
to the scorn and rejection of people just
like us.

1421.44.text:
he loved us and sent his Son to be the propitiation
for our sins- the Son became the propitiation,

1430.68.text:
he took the wrath, for our sins… the Son,
the 2nd person in the eternal, mind blowing

1438.12.text:
loving trinity, that Son, beloved of the Father
and the Spirit, was willingly sent to the

1443.88.text:
cross where instead of love, he received the
full force of the Father’s holy wrath and

1450.82.text:
cried out ‘My God, my God why have you forsaken
me’. That’s the cost of God’s love for

1469.93.text:
us.
So to end what does this mean for how we love…Our

1479.62.text:
final application (point 7 on your outline)
is that true love unchangingly loves the unlovely

1486.76.text:
despite the cost.
Jesus commands us ‘Love each other, as I

1492.73.text:
have loved you.’ Jn 15:12 So that means
love unchangingly: love is an emotion, but

1499.22.text:
it is also a decision- so we are to love others
consistently, for the long term, faithfully,

1505.47.text:
and not because something in them provokes
our love, but because it is in our nature

1511.91.text:
to love.
Which then means we love them despite them

1516.81.text:
being unlovely and despite the cost. We are
to be other person centred, but not just to

1523.94.text:
the easy people, but to the unlovely people.
Love them even when loving them is very difficult

1531.24.text:
and painful- love them for loves sake.
So think now for a moment about the people

1541.00.text:
you find the most unlovely in your life- maybe
it’s a relative who you’ve got a long

1547.80.text:
term issue with, or an incredibly difficult
work colleague. Maybe it’s that inconvenient

1553.34.text:
and time consuming person. Maybe it’s someone
who has hurt you badly and won’t and probably

1561.12.text:
never will acknowledge it… Now, firstly
think how you can love God, with respect to

1569.52.text:
these people…and we know from part 1 that
loving God means obeying him in these relationships.

1578.69.text:
And then secondly make a decision to love
those people unchangingly, despite the cost.

1586.81.text:
Now for lots of us that does mean getting
right back into a relationship that we’ve

1591.21.text:
purposefully avoided. For a few, it won’t
mean simply returning to an old relationship

1596.45.text:
that puts you at risk - but it will mean changing
your mind set towards that person to an attitude

1603.90.text:
of love and praying for their good.
And whatever the situation we’re in, we

1610.30.text:
know it will be costly, and it will be for
the long term- we are not to change loving.

1617.51.text:
But that’s how God loves us and Jesus says
‘My command is this: Love each other as
